reviewText: This is a "B" musical from Columbia Pictures in 1940.  The acting is poor, the music (with one exception)is forgettable, the comedy is pathetic, and Rita Hayworth is utterly wasted.  The only bright spot is the voice of Tony Martin. Still, he's wasted too, having to pretend that he can sing opera.Save your money.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Rita Hayworth plays a classy gal named Patricia, a woman who is about to be married to Charles (Anal Mowbray), a very rich but much older man. When her cab collides with another cab, she and Bob (Tony Martin), the other rider, end up in the same cab. Patricia takes command of the destination telling Bob she's on the way to her wedding. She never lets him get in the fact that he must make the midnight boat leaving to deport him or end up in jail.They both miss their destinations and fate steps in as two hearts become one in a whirlwind romance that includes some great musical numbers penned by Robert Wright and Chet Forrest and crooned by Martin. Ultimately, Patricia faces a hard decision, stay true to the man she's betrothed to and the one with the wealth, or listen to her heart and gamble on a man who might not be allowed to stay in the country.Some very funny moments emerge from the cast, including George Tobias as a phony Russian aristocrat.It's not brain science but the film is entertaining, thanks mostly to the talented Hayworth and charming Martin.
summary: The Love Goddess in one of her early musicals

reviewText: If I could time travel I'd go back to 1940s Hollywood and advise Margarita Cansino, then a starlet, to do more musicals. Two of my all-time favorite musicals are You'll Never Get Rich (1941) and You Were Never Lovelier (1942) in which she was cast opposite Fred Astaire. Cansino, half-Spanish beauty who can dance like the dickens, once remarked, "I guess the only jewels of my life were the pictures I made with Fred Astaire." And by Margarita Cansino, I, of course, mean Rita Hayworth.If I could time travel I'd go back and tell Alvin Morris to- oh, never mind. I don't know that a lot of folks recognize Tony Martin, which is the stage name Alvin Morris adopted when he went to Hollywood. Martin has got that velvet voice and an amiable way about him. In 1940's Music In My Heart, he plays Bob Gregory, an impatient understudy in a theatre production of The Gay Guardsman. And Bob really gets impatient when he learns that the Immigration Department wants him to ship out of the country by midnight (blame his parents for failing to put in those citizenship papers). The show's star learns of Bob's plight and takes pity on him. He feigns a sickness and there's Bob going on stage to sing and there's us getting clued in to Tony Martin's velvet voice.I don't know how long a show the Gay Guardsman is, but our film lasts only around 69 minutes. Anyway, Bob is enroute to Pier 7 and then places offshore when his cab collides with another cab. In that other cab - now rendered out of service - emerges lovely Patricia O'Malley (Cansin- I mean, Hayworth). Patricia, we learn, is also on her way to Pier 7, to marry a newspaper mogul worth six million. And because Patricia is so obviously a nice kid, let's call her "practical" rather than "mercenary." Anyway, the boat's sailed without the two. Bob is now a fugitive with an arrest warrant out for him. A considerate Patricia offers him temporary lodging at her Uncle Luigi's. Aaand more stuff happens.It's a shame that Rita Hayworth, despite being an accomplished dancer, only has one tiny moment to strut her stuff. Music In My Heart is more of a showcase for Tony Martin's buttery vocals. His rendition of "It's a Blue World" earns the it an Oscar nomination for Best Song. He also does justice to a tune titled "Oh What a Lovely Dream." But what sold me was the rollicking "Punchinello," a merry operetta-style composition which he enthusiastically belts out at a block party and directed at Uncle Luigi's stuck-up-a-lamp-post organ grinder monkey (whose name is Punchinello). I liked the song even before it shifted gears and the swing music kicked in. Martin merrily croons, "Oh, Punchinello, don't be a downhearted fellow."Will the cheerful but cynical girl recognize the gilded cage? Will the understudy be deported? Will Uncle Luigi sort out his rent problems (he's way behind on payments)? Will that monkey ever get off that lamp post? And where does Charles Spencer Gardner III (Alan Mowbray) fit in, him what's affianced to Patricia before she missed the boat? The supporting cast helps to liven things up. Mowbray is the lovestruck print mogul who's willing to give our girl another chance (and then another and then another). Eric Blore plays his conniving butler, one of them sneaky busy-bodies who meddle and manipulate in service of his master. A particular delight for me is Edith Fellows who plays Hayworth's sweet younger sister Mary and who impressed as the precocious orphan in Pennies from Heaven (1936). Here, she gets a chance or two to showcase her singing and to play matchmaker. George Tobias is another familiar face from them early days. He's the cordial Russian expatriate sporting that fake facial hair (because, he reasons, no one would believe he's Russian unless he had that bushy beard). Anyway, as modest comedic musicals go, this one's not at all shabby. And as good as the supporting actors are, as rich as Tony Martin's vocals are, as hilarious as George Tobias's wild facial hair is, the big draw is that Music In My Heart happens to be one of Rita Hayworth's stepping stones to stardom. Aren't you curious?
summary: Tony Martin serenades a monkey... and Rita Hayworth

reviewText: Early years of Margarita. Good music and it is just enchanting to see Rita Hayworth dancing on the table. She delivered her lines quite well. What set Rita Hayworth apart from others is her natural dancing gift which will live on and apreciated years after her passing away.
